frameDefinitions: This frame consists of words that indicate the change of an Item's position on a scale (the Attribute) from a starting point (Initial_value) to an end point (Final_value).
An Item changes its physical size.
The words in this frame describe the 'fictive' motion of a stationary Road.
This frame concerns rituals performed in line with religious beliefs or tradition.
An  Agent or non-human Cause causes an Item to change its physical size.
An Entity comes into existence at a particular Place and Time which may take a certain Duration_of_endstate, have a Cause, or be formed from Components.
frameExamples: Hawke's Bay winery <t>doubled</t> in size last year.
The pile of leaves had <t>shrunk</t> by about half after the first haul.
The long mountain road <t>meandered</t> through the woods.
In certain fertility <t>rites</t> in Burma , a woman desirous of offspring is required not only to approach the King Cobra but to plant a kiss on its mouth .
If the design crashes too often, then try <t>lengthening</t> the wings by a few centimeters, to perhaps 30cm total.  CNI INI
Problems may <t>arise</t> whenever an S1 sophont enters the game.
listRoleDefinitions: The <fen>Attribute</fen> is a scalar property that the <fen>Item</fen> possesses.
The entity that has a position on the scale.
The distance by which an <fen>Item</fen> changes its position on the scale.
The position on the scale where the <fen>Item</fen> ends up.
The initial position on the scale from which the <fen>Item</fen> moves away.
A portion of the scale, typically identified by its end points, along which the values of the <fen>Attribute</fen> fluctuate.
A description that presents the <fen>Item</fen>'s state before the change in the <fen>Attribute</fen>'s value as an independent predication.
A description that presents the <fen>Item</fen>'s state after  the change in the <fen>Attribute</fen>'s value as an independent predication.
The <fen>Time</fen> is the time-frame in which the change of position occurs.
A location where Attribute is measured
This role identifies the <fen>Item</fen> whose size changes.
This role identifies the <fen>Time</fen> when the expansion occurs.

Any expression which implies a definite starting-point of the <fen>Road</fen>. In prepositional phrases, the prepositional object expresses the starting point of motion. In particles, the starting point of motion is understood from context.
The trajectory that would be followed by one moving on the <fen>Road</fen>.
Any expression which tells where the fictive mover travelling along a <fen>Road</fen> would end up.

A physical path that a virtual moving entity can be imagined to travel along.
<fex name='Road'>The bike trail</fex> <t>zigzagged</t> through the woods.
This frame element is used for expressions which describe a general area in which motion takes place when the motion is understood to be irregular and not to consist of a single linear path.
The configuration formed by the entire <fen>Path</fen> along the <fen>Road</fen>.
The direction in which a 'fictive' mover would travel along a <fen>Road</fen>.

The time when the fictive motion takes place.  This may describe the time when the <fen>Road</fen> or a particular piece of the <fen>Road</fen> existed, or it may implicitly describe the time when an actual motion event occurred on the <fen>Road</fen>.
The <fen>Place</fen> is where the motion (which is specified by a <fen>Source</fen>, <fen>Path</fen> or <fen>Goal</fen>) is located.
This is the religious or cultural leader who performs and/or leads the rite.
The role <fen>Member</fen> describes the member of the religious or cultural group who participates in/undergoes the rite.
<fen>Organization</fen> identifies the institution in which the rite is prescribed.
This role identifies the <fen>Instrument</fen> used to perform a particular rite.
This role identifies the state which the rite is hoped or intended to bring about.
The type of ritual or ceremony being performed.
This role indicates an object on which a rite is performed.
Rites may confer a <fen>New_status</fen> on a participant (e.g. rank, membership).
The <fen>Guardian</fen> is the member of the <fen>Organization</fen> who instigates the rite for someone of which they are a guardian.
When the rite is performed
Where the rite takes place.
With some words in this frame, an <fen>Agent</fen> who causes the change in size of the <fen>Item</fen> may be present. The <fen>Agent</fen> typically occurs as the External Argument of a verb.
The <fen>Item</fen> is frequently the External Argument of verbs or the NP Object if an <fen>Agent</fen> is expressed.
The <fen>Cause</fen> is a non-human entity which brings about the change in size.
This role identifies the <fen>Time</fen> when the <fen>Agent</fen> causes the <fen>Item</fen> to expand.
This role identifies the <fen>Place</fen> where the <fen>Agent</fen> cause the expansion of the <fen>Item</fen>.
Concrete or abstract entity that did not exist before the <fen>Time</fen> of the event.
This role identifes the Time when a new Entity comes into existence.
This is the Place where the new Entity comes into being.
listRoleExamples: I fear <fex>this service</fex> will diminish in quality.
Diesels have increased <fex>from having a 20% market share in 1995</fex> to just over 30% in 2004.

It was never bad (1 or 2 seizures a year), but this past decade, it has increased
<fex>to having them 1 day a month</fex> and on that 1 day I have 6 or 7 seizures.
<fex>Joan's new sweater</fex> shrank to a size that might fit a doll.
The Way descends <fex>from the City of the Peak</fex> through a dense forest.
The pass dips <fex>down</fex> about 2000 feet, and then <fex>back up</fex> again.
<fex>Thousands of years ago</fex>, the Roman roads criss-crossed this landscape.
<fex>In the mountains</fex>, Highway 60 winds and swerves a lot, so we lost a couple of hours from my estimate.
His baptism <fex>into the Catholic Church</fex> is scheduled for next Sunday.
Elliott was almost ordained <fex>as a priest</fex>
<fex>Mr. and Mrs. Wilson</fex> baptized their son.

sourceCandidateSpans.text: Two Insights Don't Make A Theory (International Socialism
More Years for the Locust, London 1997
Western Capitalism Since the War, London 1968
Design and Art Direction at the Hilton Hotel)
Falling Growth and Rampant Costs: Two Ghosts in the Machine of Modern Capitalism, International Socialism
